clusters.title: U.S., China both have "credible leverage" ahead of meeting, expert says
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump and Xi Jinping Meet to Discuss Trade and Tariffs

items.title: U.S., China both have "credible leverage" ahead of meeting, expert says
items.standfirst: Amid a back-and-forth tariff war between two of the world's biggest economies, President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are preparing to meet in a matter of hours. In South Korea, Mr. Trump is seeking to make progress with Xi in his first in-person meeting with China's leader since returning to the White House. Ian Bremmer, president and founder of Eurasia Group, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: Amid a back-and-forth tariff war between two of the world's biggest economies, President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are preparing to meet in a matter of hours. In South Korea, Mr. Trump is seeking to make progress with Xi in his first in-person meeting with China's leader since returning to the White House. Ian Bremmer, president and founder of Eurasia Group, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.

items.title: What would a Trump win look like from talks with China's Xi Jinping?
items.standfirst: President Trump is in South Korea ahead of his highly anticipated meeting with China's Xi Jinping. On Wednesday, Mr. Trump finalized a trade deal with his South Korean counterparts that will lower tariffs on the country and bring new investment into U.S. industries. Ed O'Keefe has more.
items.content: President Trump is in South Korea ahead of his highly anticipated meeting with China's Xi Jinping. On Wednesday, Mr. Trump finalized a trade deal with his South Korean counterparts that will lower tariffs on the country and bring new investment into U.S. industries. Ed O'Keefe has more.

items.title: What is the US-South Korea deal looking like?
items.standfirst: U.S. and South Korea have made progress on their fraught trade deal. On the final leg of President Donald Trump's tour of Asia, he met with his South Korean counterpart Lee Jae Myung. No agreement has officially been signed but Trump lauded the day as a "tremendous success" and said things were "pretty much finalised" while Seoul officials revealed a framework that includes gradual investments and cooperation on shipbuilding as well as reduced tariffs on South Korea's auto industry.
items.content: U.S. and South Korea have made progress on their fraught trade deal. On the final leg of President Donald Trump's tour of Asia, he met with his South Korean counterpart Lee Jae Myung. No agreement has officially been signed but Trump lauded the day as a "tremendous success" and said things were "pretty much finalised" while Seoul officials revealed a framework that includes gradual investments and cooperation on shipbuilding as well as reduced tariffs on South Korea's auto industry.

The meeting occurred amid ongoing trade tensions and tariff disputes between the two nations.
Discussions included tariffs, fentanyl, and rare-earth minerals, among other topics.

clusters.title: What the Fed's rate cut means for your wallet
clusters.neutral_headline: Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates Again Amid Economic Concerns

items.title: What the Fed's rate cut means for your wallet
items.standfirst: The Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates for the second time in a row. The Fed announced a quarter of a percentage point rate cut, which falls in line with what economists expected. CBS News MoneyWatch correspondent Kelly O'Grady has more.
items.content: The Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates for the second time in a row. The Fed announced a quarter of a percentage point rate cut, which falls in line with what economists expected. CBS News MoneyWatch correspondent Kelly O'Grady has more.

items.title: US Federal Reserve cuts rates again but cautions another in December is far from certain
items.standfirst: The US Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates for the second time this year, despite having only partial data to assess the state of the economy because of the ongoing government shutdown. The quarter percentage point cut brings the Federal Funds Rate to a range of 3.75% to 4%. The central bank also announced it would stop reducing the size of its balance sheet in December. Also in the segment, Boeing posted $5.4 billion in third-quarter loss weighed down by delays in its 777X rollout.
items.content: The US Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates for the second time this year, despite having only partial data to assess the state of the economy because of the ongoing government shutdown. The quarter percentage point cut brings the Federal Funds Rate to a range of 3.75% to 4%. The central bank also announced it would stop reducing the size of its balance sheet in December. Also in the segment, Boeing posted $5.4 billion in third-quarter loss weighed down by delays in its 777X rollout.

items.title: Why the Fed cut interest rates again despite inflation remaining above target

items.title: Fed cuts interest rates for second time this year amid economic uncertainty
items.standfirst: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffsThe US Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday, the second rate cut this year amid economic turbulence from the federal government shutdown and Donald Trump’s tariffs.The decision to cut the Fed’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% comes at an extraordinary moment for the central bank. The Fed has been under immense pressure from Donald Trump to cut rates despite persistent inflation and no longer has access to key data thanks to the shutdown. Continue reading...
items.content: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffsThe US Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday, the second rate cut this year amid economic turbulence from the federal government shutdown and Donald Trump’s tariffs.The decision to cut the Fed’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% comes at an extraordinary moment for the central bank. The Fed has been under immense pressure from Donald Trump to cut rates despite persistent inflation and no longer has access to key data thanks to the shutdown. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Louvre heist suspects face theft and conspiracy charges
clusters.neutral_headline: Louvre Heist Suspects Face Theft and Conspiracy Charges

items.title: Louvre heist suspects face theft and conspiracy charges
items.standfirst: Two men arrested over the jewel heist at France's Louvre museum this month will be charged with theft and criminal conspiracy, the Paris prosecutor said Wednesday. Dozens of detectives have been on the trail of four thieves who used a cherry-picker truck and cutting gear to break into a first-floor gallery at the world-renowned museum, then fled with jewellery estimated to be worth more than $102 million. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris-Trent reports.
items.content: Two men arrested over the jewel heist at France's Louvre museum this month will be charged with theft and criminal conspiracy, the Paris prosecutor said Wednesday. Dozens of detectives have been on the trail of four thieves who used a cherry-picker truck and cutting gear to break into a first-floor gallery at the world-renowned museum, then fled with jewellery estimated to be worth more than $102 million. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris-Trent reports.

items.title: Two suspects in Louvre heist partially admit involvement: Paris prosecutor
items.standfirst: The suspects face charges for theft committed by an organised gang and criminal conspiracy, prosecutor says.
items.content: The suspects face charges for theft committed by an organised gang and criminal conspiracy, prosecutor says.

items.title: Louvre suspects ‘partially admit’ their role in jewel heist
items.standfirst: Police are no closer to recovering gems valued at £76m, despite the arrest of two men last weekTwo men arrested on suspicion of stealing crown jewels worth an estimated €88m (£76m) from the Louvre in Paris have “partially admitted” their role in the heist, the prosecutor has said, but police are no closer to recovering the gems.Laure Beccuau said the pair, arrested on Sunday, would be brought before magistrates “with a view to being charged with organised theft, which carries a 15-year prison sentence, and criminal conspiracy, punishable by 10 years”. Continue reading...
items.content: Police are no closer to recovering gems valued at £76m, despite the arrest of two men last weekTwo men arrested on suspicion of stealing crown jewels worth an estimated €88m (£76m) from the Louvre in Paris have “partially admitted” their role in the heist, the prosecutor has said, but police are no closer to recovering the gems.Laure Beccuau said the pair, arrested on Sunday, would be brought before magistrates “with a view to being charged with organised theft, which carries a 15-year prison sentence, and criminal conspiracy, punishable by 10 years”. Continue reading...

items.title: Two suspects partially admit involvement in Louvre heist, prosecutor says
items.standfirst: The Paris prosecutor says the jewels are not yet recovered and there could be a bigger gang behind the theft.
items.content: The Paris prosecutor says the jewels are not yet recovered and there could be a bigger gang behind the theft.

items.title: Replay: watch the Paris prosecutor's update on the Louvre heist investigation
items.standfirst: Watch Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau's awaited address, as she gives updates on the Louvre heist ongoing investigation. She announced that the two suspects would be charged with theft and conspiracy and have 'partially' admitted their participation.
items.content: Watch Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau's awaited address, as she gives updates on the Louvre heist ongoing investigation. She announced that the two suspects would be charged with theft and conspiracy and have 'partially' admitted their participation.

items.title: Officials address inside job theory over Louvre heist
items.standfirst: The two suspects arrested over the Louvre jewellery heist have "partially" confessed to their involvement in the robbery, according to a prosecutor.
items.content: The two suspects arrested over the Louvre jewellery heist have "partially" confessed to their involvement in the robbery, according to a prosecutor.

ai_summary: Two suspects in the Louvre jewel heist will be charged with theft and conspiracy.
The suspects partially admitted their involvement in the theft.
The stolen jewels are estimated to be worth over $102 million.
Police are still working to recover the stolen jewels.
The prosecutor announced the charges after the suspects' arrest.

clusters.title: Sudanese RSF militia killed many civilians at hospital, WHO chief and doctors say
clusters.neutral_headline: Reports of Mass Killings in Sudan's El-Fasher Emerge

items.title: Sudanese RSF militia killed many civilians at hospital, WHO chief and doctors say
items.standfirst: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said he was "appalled" by reports that 460 civilians had been killed in el-Fasher.
items.content: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said he was "appalled" by reports that 460 civilians had been killed in el-Fasher.

items.title: Tens of thousands killed in two days in Sudan city, analysts believe
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people have been killed in the Sudanese city of Al Fashir by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in a two-day window after the paramilitary group captured the regional capital, analysts believe.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people have been killed in the Sudanese city of Al Fashir by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in a two-day window after the paramilitary group captured the regional capital, analysts believe.

items.title: Hundreds reportedly killed at Sudanese hospital as evidence of RSF atrocities mounts
items.standfirst: Rapid Support Forces, which claimed control of El Fasher on Sunday, reportedly killed at least 460 people ‘in cold blood’Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces killed hundreds of patients and staff inside a hospital in El Fasher, according to the World Health Organization and the Sudan Doctors Network, after the paramilitary group claimed control of the city on Sunday.The WHO secretary general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said he was “appalled and deeply shocked” at reports that more than 460 people had been killed at the Saudi maternity hospital, without assigning blame, in a post on X. Continue reading...
items.content: Rapid Support Forces, which claimed control of El Fasher on Sunday, reportedly killed at least 460 people ‘in cold blood’Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces killed hundreds of patients and staff inside a hospital in El Fasher, according to the World Health Organization and the Sudan Doctors Network, after the paramilitary group claimed control of the city on Sunday.The WHO secretary general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said he was “appalled and deeply shocked” at reports that more than 460 people had been killed at the Saudi maternity hospital, without assigning blame, in a post on X. Continue reading...

items.title: Genocide warnings 'flashing red' after RSF takeover of Sudan's El-Fasher
items.standfirst: Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have seized the western city of El-Fasher amid reports of extreme violence and mass killings. The capture of the key city in the Darfur region is a strategic boon for the paramilitary group, raising fears that Sudan’s ongoing civil war will enter a new phase of escalation.
items.content: Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have seized the western city of El-Fasher amid reports of extreme violence and mass killings. The capture of the key city in the Darfur region is a strategic boon for the paramilitary group, raising fears that Sudan’s ongoing civil war will enter a new phase of escalation.

items.title: Mass killings reported in Sudanese city seized by paramilitary group
items.standfirst: Rapid Support Forces accused of killing more than 2,000 unarmed civilians in El Fasher in recent daysReports of ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are emerging from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.Video released by local activists showed a fighter known for executing civilians in RSF-controlled areas shooting a group of unarmed civilians sitting on the ground at point-blank range. Continue reading...
items.content: Rapid Support Forces accused of killing more than 2,000 unarmed civilians in El Fasher in recent daysReports of ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are emerging from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.Video released by local activists showed a fighter known for executing civilians in RSF-controlled areas shooting a group of unarmed civilians sitting on the ground at point-blank range. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) are accused of killing civilians in El-Fasher.
The World Health Organization reported hundreds killed at a hospital.
Analysts believe tens of thousands were killed in the city.
The RSF captured El-Fasher, a strategic city in the Darfur region.
Genocide warnings are "flashing red" after the RSF takeover.

clusters.title: Israel strikes Gaza again after overnight bombardment that killed at least 104
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel and Hamas Ceasefire Fragile After Gaza Strikes

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza again after overnight bombardment that killed at least 104
items.standfirst: Attacks shatter Palestinians’ short-lived relief since start of ceasefire that now looks increasingly fragileIsrael carried out another strike in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, killing at least two people, after bombarding the territory overnight and killing at least 104 Palestinians, including children, in the gravest challenge yet to the increasingly fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The Israeli military said it had struck military infrastructure where weapons were being stored for an imminent attack in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City said it had received two bodies from the strike. Continue reading...
items.content: Attacks shatter Palestinians’ short-lived relief since start of ceasefire that now looks increasingly fragileIsrael carried out another strike in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, killing at least two people, after bombarding the territory overnight and killing at least 104 Palestinians, including children, in the gravest challenge yet to the increasingly fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The Israeli military said it had struck military infrastructure where weapons were being stored for an imminent attack in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City said it had received two bodies from the strike. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel carries out fresh strike on Gaza and accuses Hamas of preparing 'imminent terror attack'
items.standfirst: The Israeli military says it has carried out a fresh strike on Gaza, in a move that will further raise concerns about the fragility of its ceasefire with Hamas.
items.content: The Israeli military says it has carried out a fresh strike on Gaza, in a move that will further raise concerns about the fragility of its ceasefire with Hamas.

items.title: Israel says it's resuming the ceasefire after its strikes in Gaza kill over 100 people
items.standfirst: Israel's military said the ceasefire in Gaza resumed after it carried out heavy airstrikes overnight that killed 104 people, including 46 children, according to local health officials.
items.content: Israel's military said the ceasefire in Gaza resumed after it carried out heavy airstrikes overnight that killed 104 people, including 46 children, according to local health officials.(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

items.title: Israel says ceasefire back on after strikes kill more than 100 in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel said Wednesday that the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip was back on after it carried out intense strikes across the Palestinian enclave that killed 100 people, including children, according to local health officials
items.content: Israel said Wednesday that the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip was back on after it carried out intense strikes across the Palestinian enclave that killed 100 people, including children, according to local health officials

items.title: Wednesday briefing: ‘Catastrophic’ reports as Jamaica reels from worst storm since records began
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: Meteorologists have called it ‘a dire situation unfolding in slow motion’ – what will it leave behind?Good morning. Hurricane Melissa, the strongest storm to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, made landfall at about midday local time on Tuesday. With winds reaching 185mph and torrential rains, it knocked out power lines, cut off the internet, and demolished buildings; the death toll and extent of the damage are still unknown.The storm has already hit Haiti and the Dominican Republic; though it was at one stage downgraded to a tropical storm, now it has strengthened again and is expected to arrive imminently in Cuba, where more than 700,000 people have been evacuated. “The reports that are coming in are catastrophic,” Jamaican energy and transport minister Daryl Vaz told Sky News. “Not very much survives a Category 5 hurricane, in terms of infrastructure.”Economy | Rachel Reeves has said Britain can defy gloomy economic forecasts after the fiscal watchdog infuriated ministers by predicting a productivity downgrade would leave her with a £20bn gap to fill in her forthcoming budget.Sudan | Ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are being reported from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.UK news | Downing Street has defended the prospect of paying more to house asylum seekers in disused barracks instead of hotels, arguing that quelling public disquiet was worth the extra cost. No 10 said that “communities don’t want asylum seekers housed in hotels, and neither does the government”.Middle East | Israeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Television | Prunella Scales, the actor best known for playing Sybil Fawlty in the classic comedy series Fawlty Towers, has died aged 93. Scales, who was married to fellow actor Timothy West, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease in 2013. Continue reading...

Scales, who was married to fellow actor Timothy West, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease in 2013. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
items.standfirst: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Meta reports mixed financial results amid spree of AI hiring and spending
clusters.neutral_headline: Meta and Alphabet Report Mixed Financial Results

items.title: Meta reports mixed financial results amid spree of AI hiring and spending
items.standfirst: Tech company brings in record quarterly revenue but major tax bill dampens earnings per shareMeta reported mixed financial results for the third quarter of 2025. The company brought in record quarterly revenue but reported a major tax bill that dampened earnings per share, the company announced on Wednesday. The financial results come as Meta ends a multibillion-dollar hiring spree focused on artificial intelligence talent.The tech giant earned $51.24bn in quarterly revenue, beating Wall Street’s expectations and the company’s own projections for third-quarter sales. However, it reported earnings per share (EPS) of $1.05, far below Wall Street expectations of $6.70 in EPS. The major drop was due to a one-time non-cash income tax charge of $15.93bn. The EPS would have been $7.25 without this one-time charge, the company said. Continue reading...
items.content: Tech company brings in record quarterly revenue but major tax bill dampens earnings per shareMeta reported mixed financial results for the third quarter of 2025. The company brought in record quarterly revenue but reported a major tax bill that dampened earnings per share, the company announced on Wednesday. The financial results come as Meta ends a multibillion-dollar hiring spree focused on artificial intelligence talent.The tech giant earned $51.24bn in quarterly revenue, beating Wall Street’s expectations and the company’s own projections for third-quarter sales. However, it reported earnings per share (EPS) of $1.05, far below Wall Street expectations of $6.70 in EPS. The major drop was due to a one-time non-cash income tax charge of $15.93bn. The EPS would have been $7.25 without this one-time charge, the company said. Continue reading...

items.title: Google parent Alphabet beats forecasts with first $100bn quarter
items.standfirst: Strong demand for ads and cloud services powered tech giant’s growth as it makes multibillion-dollar AI investmentGoogle’s parent company, Alphabet, displayed steady growth in its core advertising business and cloud computing division as it reported third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, beating Wall Street estimates as it reported its first quarter of $100bn in revenue.The company thrilled Wall Street – shares rose in after-hours trading – even as it announced that it would spend billions more than previously predicted. Alphabet raised its capital expenditure guidance in financial filings, declaring it would spend between $91bn and $93bn in the upcoming year, nearly all of it on infrastructure like datacenters to support artificial intelligence products, which are becoming an integral part of the company’s business. That estimate is up from an original declaration of $75bn in February and a revised figure of $85bn announced in July. Continue reading...
items.content: Strong demand for ads and cloud services powered tech giant’s growth as it makes multibillion-dollar AI investmentGoogle’s parent company, Alphabet, displayed steady growth in its core advertising business and cloud computing division as it reported third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, beating Wall Street estimates as it reported its first quarter of $100bn in revenue.The company thrilled Wall Street – shares rose in after-hours trading – even as it announced that it would spend billions more than previously predicted. Alphabet raised its capital expenditure guidance in financial filings, declaring it would spend between $91bn and $93bn in the upcoming year, nearly all of it on infrastructure like datacenters to support artificial intelligence products, which are becoming an integral part of the company’s business. That estimate is up from an original declaration of $75bn in February and a revised figure of $85bn announced in July. Continue reading...

clusters.title: US Democratic congressional candidate indicted for Chicago ICE protest
clusters.neutral_headline: US Congressional Candidate Indicted After ICE Protest

items.title: US Democratic congressional candidate indicted for Chicago ICE protest
items.standfirst: Candidate Kat Abughazaleh decried the charges as 'political prosecution' amid a Trump standoff with Democratic cities.
items.content: Candidate Kat Abughazaleh decried the charges as 'political prosecution' amid a Trump standoff with Democratic cities.

items.title: Progressive House candidate indicted amid Chicago-area ICE protests
items.standfirst: Kat Abughazaleh, a Democrat running for an open House seat, said the charges are “unjust.”
items.content: Kat Abughazaleh, a progressive Democrat running for an open House seat in Illinois, faces federal charges after attending a protest at a U.S. Immigration Customs and Enforcement processing center outside Chicago. Abughazaleh, a social media influencer who recently moved to the state, was charged with conspiracy to impede or injure a federal officer and assaulting or impeding an officer as they engaged in official duties at the Broadview ICE detention center. According to the indictment, Abughazaleh was among several protesters who in September allegedly surrounded a government vehicle, banged on the hood and windows and scratched the body of the car, including etching the word “PIG” into the vehicle. The indictment also alleges the protesters broke one of the vehicle’s side mirrors and a rear windshield wiper. Video of the encounter that day, posted by Abughazaleh, showed her and protesters placing their hands on the vehicle as the agent continued to slowly drive forward into the line of protesters, with some banging on the car. Abughazaleh is one of the more than a dozen Democratic candidates running for Congress to fill the seat now held by Rep. Jan Schakowsky, who announced earlier this year that she won't seek reelection in 2026. In a statement, Abughazaleh called the charges “political prosecution” and a “gross attempt to silence dissent.” “This case is yet another attempt by the Trump administration to criminalize protest and punish those who dare to speak up,” Abughazaleh said, adding that the charges are “unjust.” Other political figures named in the indictment include Catherine Sharp, a chief of staff to a Chicago alderman and a candidate for Cook County Board; Michael Rabbitt, a Chicago Democratic ward committeeman; and Brian Straw, a member of the suburban Oak Park Village board. Sharp's attorney, Molly Armour, called the charges "ludicrous," saying, "we are confident that a jury of Ms. Sharp’s peers will see them for exactly what they are: an effort by the Trump administration to frighten people out of participating in protest and exercising their First Amendment rights.” The Department of Justice did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Advocates and politicians have protested regularly outside the Broadview detention center since President Donald Trump ordered ICE agents into the city to conduct mass arrests. Abughazaleh has previously protested outside the center, including at least once prior when she was teargassed and thrown to the ground by an ICE agent. Following the release of the indictment, Evanston mayor Daniel Biss — who is also running for the seat — called the charges “frivolous” and accused ICE of engaging in “violent and dangerous behavior at Broadview.” “As someone who has protested at Broadview multiple times, I know these protests are nonviolent demonstrations against the kidnapping of our neighbors,” Biss said in a statement posted on X. “Now, the Trump Administration is targeting protestors, including political candidates, in an effort to silence dissent and scare residents into submission. It won’t work.”

ai_summary: Kat Abughazaleh, a Democratic candidate, was indicted.
The charges stem from protests against ICE in Chicago.
Abughazaleh described the charges as "political prosecution."
The indictment occurred amid a standoff with Democratic cities.
Abughazaleh is running for an open House seat.

items.title: Three Monkeys Still on the Loose after Truck's Crash in Mississippi
items.standfirst: Three monkeys remained on the loose in rural Mississippi on Wednesday after a truck carrying research animals overturned, leaving authorities scrambling to track them down and raising questions about who owned the animals and where they were headed. The Jasper County Sheriff’s Department said the…
items.content: Three monkeys remained on the loose in rural Mississippi on Wednesday after a truck carrying research animals overturned, leaving authorities scrambling to track them down and raising questions about who owned the animals and where they were headed. The Jasper County Sheriff’s Department said the…

ai_summary: Three monkeys escaped after a truck carrying research animals overturned in Mississippi.
Authorities are working to locate the monkeys in rural Mississippi.
The Jasper County Sheriff’s Department is involved in the search.
Questions remain regarding the ownership and destination of the monkeys.
The incident occurred on a highway in Mississippi on Tuesday.

clusters.title: Pound sinks against euro and dollar as tax rises loom and growth slows
clusters.neutral_headline: Pound Sinks Against Euro and Dollar

items.title: Pound sinks against euro and dollar as tax rises loom and growth slows
items.standfirst: Prospect of a tough budget is thought to have brought forward the likely date for a cut in interest rates to 3.75% The threat of higher taxes in next month’s budget and concerns about slowing economic growth pushed the pound to its lowest level against the euro in more than two and a half years on…
items.content: Prospect of a tough budget is thought to have brought forward the likely date for a cut in interest rates to 3.75% The threat of higher taxes in next month’s budget and concerns about slowing economic growth pushed the pound to its lowest level against the euro in more than two and a half years on…

items.title: Pound sinks against euro and dollar as tax rises loom and growth slows
items.standfirst: Prospect of a tough budget is thought to have brought forward the likely date for a cut in interest rates to 3.75%The threat of higher taxes in next month’s budget and concerns about slowing economic growth pushed the pound to its lowest level against the euro in more than two and a half years at one point on Wednesday.Sterling also slumped against the dollar as traders digested news that Rachel Reeves will need to fill a larger hole in the public finances when she puts together her budget plan, after a bigger-than-expected downgrade to the UK’s productivity outlook. Continue reading...
items.content: Prospect of a tough budget is thought to have brought forward the likely date for a cut in interest rates to 3.75%The threat of higher taxes in next month’s budget and concerns about slowing economic growth pushed the pound to its lowest level against the euro in more than two and a half years at one point on Wednesday.Sterling also slumped against the dollar as traders digested news that Rachel Reeves will need to fill a larger hole in the public finances when she puts together her budget plan, after a bigger-than-expected downgrade to the UK’s productivity outlook. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The pound fell against the euro and dollar.
Tax increases are expected in the upcoming budget.
Concerns about slowing economic growth contributed to the decline.
The pound reached its lowest level against the euro in over two years.
Interest rate cuts may be brought forward to 3.75%.

items.title: Paramount begins 2,000-person layoff amid Skydance merger fallout
items.standfirst: Paramount is the latest company to join the bloodbath of layoffs this week. The entertainment giant began cutting around 1,000 workers on Wednesday, with twice that many pink slips expected in the days to come. In a memo to staff, new Paramount CEO David Ellison characterized the reductions,…
items.content: Paramount is the latest company to join the bloodbath of layoffs this week. The entertainment giant began cutting around 1,000 workers on Wednesday, with twice that many pink slips expected in the days to come. In a memo to staff, new Paramount CEO David Ellison characterized the reductions,…

items.title: CBS News staffers lose jobs in ‘bloodbath’ as part of sweeping cuts from Paramount
items.standfirst: Paramount laying off about 1,000 staffers, including some in news, on Wednesday amid longer-term cost-cutting planFor months, CBS News staffers have been on edge waiting for a long-expected round of layoffs as part of the $2bn in cost-cutting that had been promised after parent company Paramount’s successful merger with Skydance Media.Those cuts began on Wednesday morning and are expected to affect fewer than 100 people. The company declined to provide a specific number. Continue reading...
items.content: Paramount laying off about 1,000 staffers, including some in news, on Wednesday amid longer-term cost-cutting planFor months, CBS News staffers have been on edge waiting for a long-expected round of layoffs as part of the $2bn in cost-cutting that had been promised after parent company Paramount’s successful merger with Skydance Media.Those cuts began on Wednesday morning and are expected to affect fewer than 100 people. The company declined to provide a specific number. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Paramount is laying off approximately 1,000 employees.
The layoffs are part of a larger cost-cutting plan.
The cuts are expected to affect fewer than 100 CBS News staffers.
The layoffs are a result of the merger with Skydance Media.
The company is cutting costs by $2 billion.

Musk Lawyer Vows Legal Fight to Unwind OpenAI Restructuring

clusters.title: Video shows destruction at Jamaica airport after Hurricane Melissa hits the island

items.title: Video shows destruction at Jamaica airport after Hurricane Melissa hits the island
items.standfirst: Video captured the destruction at Sangster International Airport in Jamaica after Category 5 Hurricane Melissa hit the island. Airport officials said they are “assessing the damage to restore operations as soon as conditions allow.”
items.content: Video captured the destruction at Sangster International Airport in Jamaica after Category 5 Hurricane Melissa hit the island. Airport officials said they are “assessing the damage to restore operations as soon as conditions allow.”

items.title: Hurricane Melissa leaves Jamaica devastated. And, the shutdown's impact on airports

clusters.title: Ex-L3Harris Cyber Boss Pleads Guilty to Selling Trade Secrets to Russian Firm
clusters.neutral_headline: Ex-L3Harris Cyber Boss Pleads Guilty to Selling Trade Secrets to Russian Firm

items.title: Ex-L3Harris Cyber Boss Pleads Guilty to Selling Trade Secrets to Russian Firm
items.standfirst: Peter Williams, a former executive of Trenchant, L3Harris’ cyber division, has pleaded guilty to two counts of stealing trade secrets and selling them to an unnamed Russian software broker.
items.content: Peter Williams, a former executive of Trenchant, L3Harris’ cyber division, has pleaded guilty to two counts of stealing trade secrets and selling them to an unnamed Russian software broker.

items.title: Hacking Firm Boss Pleads Guilty to Stealing, Selling Secrets
items.standfirst: A former director at a US military contractor that sells computer vulnerabilities pleaded guilty on Wednesday to stealing and reselling $35 million in trade secrets to a Russian cyber-tools broker whose clients include the Russian government.
items.content: A former director at a US military contractor that sells computer vulnerabilities pleaded guilty on Wednesday to stealing and reselling $35 million in trade secrets to a Russian cyber-tools broker whose clients include the Russian government.

ai_summary: Peter Williams pleaded guilty to stealing trade secrets.
Williams sold the secrets to a Russian software broker.
Williams was a former executive at L3Harris' cyber division.
The trade secrets were worth $35 million.
The Russian broker's clients included the Russian government.

clusters.title: Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka says US revoked his visa
clusters.neutral_headline: Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka says US revoked his visa

items.title: Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka says US revoked his visa
items.standfirst: The 91-year-old Nobel laureate in literature has been a critic of Trump's immigration policy.
items.content: The 91-year-old Nobel laureate in literature has been a critic of Trump's immigration policy.

items.title: Wole Soyinka, Nigerian Nobel laureate and Trump critic, says US visa revoked
items.standfirst: Soyinka, 91, who recently compared US president to Idi Amin, says ‘I have no visa – I am banned’The Trump administration has revoked the visa for Wole Soyinka, the acclaimed Nigerian Nobel prize-winning writer who has been critical of Trump since his first presidency, Soyinka revealed on Tuesday.“I want to assure the consulate … that I’m very content with the revocation of my visa,” Soyinka, who won the 1986 Nobel prize for literature, told a news conference. Continue reading...
items.content: Soyinka, 91, who recently compared US president to Idi Amin, says ‘I have no visa – I am banned’The Trump administration has revoked the visa for Wole Soyinka, the acclaimed Nigerian Nobel prize-winning writer who has been critical of Trump since his first presidency, Soyinka revealed on Tuesday.“I want to assure the consulate … that I’m very content with the revocation of my visa,” Soyinka, who won the 1986 Nobel prize for literature, told a news conference. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Wole Soyinka said the US revoked his visa.
Soyinka is a Nobel laureate in literature.
Soyinka has been critical of Trump's immigration policy.
Soyinka compared the US president to Idi Amin.
Soyinka is 91 years old.
